DataElement.preferredName: Patient Bilateral Breast Carcinoma Eligibility Determination Ind-4
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the indicator related to patient criteria to determine eligibility regarding bilateral carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Patient Bilateral Breast Carcinoma Eligibility Determination
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to patient criteria to determine eligibility regarding bilateral carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A person who requires medical care.

Concepts.definition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.

Property.preferredDefinition: Affecting both sides of the body, or a matched pair of organs.:A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit.  Breast carcinoma may affect both females and males.  It is the most common malignant tumor and the leading cause of carcinoma death in women.  Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation.  The widespread use of mammography has contributed in the detection of very early cancerous lesions (less than 2mm in diameter).  The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular).  Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route.  The most common site of lymph node involvment is the axilla.  Breast carcinomas infrequently occur in males (particularly elderly individuals and patients with Klinefelter's syndrome).  The therapy of breat carcinoma includes surgery, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy and chemotherapy, depending on the type and extend of the disease. --2002:Criteria to determine eligibility of patients for medical care programs and services.

Concepts.definition: Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.

A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.
The act of determining if a subject is suitable for enrollment in a study according specific protocol criteria and procedures.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: trial-specific criteria that a patient must meet to be enrolled.

ReferenceDocuments.name: If subject has bilateral brea
ReferenceDocuments.description: If subject has bilateral breast carcinoma diagnoses were synchronous - within 3 months of one another - and at least one of the two breast carcinomas meet the eligibility criteria and neither meets the exclusion criteria
